6 Tips to Prevent Electric Shock

More than 30,000 electric shock accidents happen each year according to the Electrical Safety Foundation International. Fortunately, electric shock is fairly easy to prevent if you know what to avoid. Here we provide six tips on how you and your family can avoid electric shock in your household.avoid electric shock

Please note, these tips are in regards to every day use of household electrical appliances. Always hire a professional for any electrical tasks, projects and installations.

  1. Cover sockets and outlets, especially if you have small children or pets. Covers can keep debris out of sockets and shield fingers from exposed wires.
  2. Have a professional educate you on how the fuses, circuit breakers, and wires are set up in your home.
  3. Any electrical equipment that shocks, sparks, short circuits, or has frayed wires should be fixed or replaced or disposed of!
  4. When storing cords, don’t let them twist or get into haphazard knots. Tuck them away so that small children cannot find them and so that pets won’t chew them.
  5. Do not have too many heavy appliances plugged in and running from one power strip. This can lead to overheating, and electrical fire or a blown fuse.
  6. Use electrical devices away from water! If something accidently falls into water while plugged in, turn off the power to the circuit before your remove the object from the water. Then unplug, dry out, and ask an electrician if it can still be used.

By: alex britva
